blocks.text: March 26, 1967 (Easter Sunday) - As a complete surprise, the four girls, Nancy, Cindy, Kathy and Louise, tell Gordon and Kitty they will send them to Europe, all expenses paid, as a present for their 30th wedding anniversary later in the year.
Gordon reads the announcement aloud while Kitty shows her disbelief.
The poem - by Louise.

blocks.text: The ruins of Jerpoint Abbey south of Kilkenny, on the road to Waterford, said to be one of the finest monastic ruins in Ireland. Founded in the twelfth century the large square tower dates from the fifteenth century.

blocks.text: Tuesday, July 18 - secure a room at the Hotel Ormonde in Dungarvan, first sleep since the morning of the previous day as Lancaster...not so much. $10 for two, breakfast included, as is the custom. Awakened twice during the night by a telephone ringing in our room, to discover the next morning there is a bellbox, but the phone itself not yet installed.
The post office retains the ancient Gaelic spelling.

In Waterford where the art of cutting fine glass has been revived, we visit the factory showroom to see some of the products that have become world famous. The town itself has a history of more than a thousand years.
Thatched cottages are a part of the rural Irish scene.

blocks.text: Sir Walter Raleigh was mayor of Youghal in 1588–1589, and here he introduced the planting of tobacco and potatoes to Ireland.
Cork, 120,000 pop., Ireland's second city, has fine harbor on inlet of the River Lee (below).

To kiss the Blarney Stone atop the battlefield of Blarney Castle near Cork is to be assured of eternal eloquence; a complicated maneuver involving going over backwards. It's "unsanitary", declares Kitty, thus debunking a legend of the centuries.

blocks.text: Strange, high country west of Kenmare at the beginning of the road around the Iveragh peninsula, which is a part of the famous "Ring of Kerry". Sheep are seen over a wide expanse.
Our rented car is an ugly breed, but it does take us where we want to go.
Farming at land's end.

blocks.text: In places the land is cultivated to the water's edge is...cultivated in forests still prevail. This is as far west as you can go in Europe. The large picture on the opposite page was enlarged from a 35 mm negative (see the actual negative size below).
Second night in Killorglin, near Dingle Bay. Dinner of fresh-caught salmon, bed (with hot water bottle) & breakfast is $7.72 for two.
A country pub at the turn of a road. The frequency of these places suggests the Irish may have a large capacity for alcoholic beverages.
In the morning, Irish farmers convey their milk to town in carts like the one shown above.
(Left) Completely restored Bunratty Castle near Shannon, open to tourist trade.

blocks.text: Thur., July 20 - Fly to Amsterdam from Shannon (3:40 to 8:05 P.M.) with change of planes in London...almost lose extra carton of cigarettes when misdirected to go through English customs...convince them we do not belong in merry England.
Amsterdam.
Two nights at the modest Hotel De Ij tunnelnei at $7.75 for two (B&B); breakfast includes cheese, meat & hard boiled egg. ccheeseesssee, mmeaaattttt & hhard oillledd eegggg..

Two of the world's greatest museums are in Amsterdam: the Rijksmuseum, devoted to classical painting, culminating in 'the work of Rembrandt and his "Night Watch", which some say is the greatest painting of all time; and the Stedelijk, which features modern art, and includes many Van Goghs and other impressionists beyond belief. Unfortunately, no pictures may be taken in either museum.

blocks.text: Canals are everywhere, fifty of them, with 500 bridges.
A one hour boat ride through Amsterdam's canals and harbor is a "must". The fare is 70¢ per person. Our guide describes attractions in four languages.
STOP de BOMBARDEMENTE
OP de BOMBAS

(Three pictures at right) A quaint square within a square just off the Kalverstraat, a busy shopping street, and almost completely hidden by a narrow entrance, is the Begijnhof, a courtyard, with seventeenth century homes, each with own rose garden, and a Presbyterian and a Catholic church. Old Amsterdam at its best.

blocks.text: In down town city, instead of hamburger and hot dog stands, you step up and buy (yes) raw herring, apparently a Dutch specialty exclusively.
After legs give out. two hours at a sidewalk cafe to watch the passing scene. The beer is good, but genever (Dutch gin), a popular aperitif, requires more cultivation than we have time available.

blocks.text: The picture above displays the city's excellent surface transportation system, and an example of some of the shortest skirts to be found in all Europe, not excluding Paris and London.
The National Monument, opposite the Royal Palace in the Dam Square in the heart of the city, is the gathering place for beatniks. of whom Amsterdam can claim a plenteous representation.

On the last day in Holland a round trip by bus and boat to Monnikendam, Marken and Volendam, towns north of Amsterdam which have retained their old-world atmosphere, with traditional costumes, houses and customs...$1.25 per person.
House boats are anchored in the channel as we approach Market.

blocks.text: In Marken we find the usual appeal to the tourist trade. It is said to the 1,500 inhabitants bear only thirty two family names, due many years of intermarriage. The attire is colorful; wooden shoes are worn by most of the people.
Fishing fleet at Volendam, two miles across the Zuider Zee from Marken.
Sailing on the Zuiders Zee.
Everywhere in Volendam we find men dressed in baggy pantaloons and women in long black skirts and aprons. We can't escape the suspicion much of it is for tourists.

blocks.text:
Saturday,
July 22 - leave Amsterdam at
2:20 P. M. by train for Frankfurt,
Germany, a trip of six hours, twenty
five minutes. The train is crowded with
American students whose informal, down-
right sloppy appearance is distasteful.
South from Frankfurt on the Autobahn, a German four-lane super highway which must not have a speed limit, for many small cars whip by us at more than eighty miles an hour.
more than eighty miles an hour.

blocks.text: We enter the region of the Black Forest, so called because spruce and pine trees grow so thickly the sun can penetrate with difficulty. It is a region of mountains, waterfalls and old world villages which stretches for a hundred miles through southern Germany to the Swiss border.

Freudenstadt is said to have the largest town square in Germany, only a part of which is shown. The sidewalks are in back of the arches in the buildings. Vacationers are everywhere, most of whom, as expected, are German.
It's time for relaxation at an outdoor cafe in Freudenstadt, a town of 14,000 with a famous spa.

blocks.text:
The Black Forest town of Schiltach,
built on a hillside, has timbered houses and frescoed buildings 'which line ancient cobblestone streets.
One of the most charming towns of the entire trip.

This cemetery, bright with flowers,
gives an over-all feeling of great beauty. Each grave is a meticulously tended garden.
Night at the outskirts of Lorrach, still in Germany, but almost on the Swiss border. Credit Louise with finding a "zimmer", clean and comfortable ($4 for 2).

Monday, July 24 - enter Switzerland in early morning after routine inspection of papers by customs. Just over border exchange travel checks for Swiss francs which Louise and Gordon hope will see them through 5½ days in Switzerland; but a later exchange is needed.

blocks.text: Basel on the Rhine River is Switzerland's second city in size with a population of 210,000. The Rhine provides direct navigable traffic for six hundred miles to Rotterdam and the North Sea. The city is of Roman origin.
Southeast of Basel is Olten, with covered foot bridge over the Aare River.

blocks.text: Luzern (Lucerne) - there are many who consider Luzern the most beautiful city in the world, for here you come upon the lofty Alps whose snow-cov ered peaks are reflected in the blue glacial waters of Lake Luzern; and the city itself, old and new, is a sightseer's paradise.
A section of the old city.
The two covered foot bridges across the River Reuss date from the 14th and 15th centuries.

blocks.text: The Lion of Luzern, carved in a limestone cliff, depicts a dying lion protecting the Bourbon fleur-de-lis of France. and commemorates the 800 Swiss mercenaries who died to the last man in defense of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette from the Paris mob in 1792.
TABAK CUCKOO-CLOCKS GONGS EISKA PLACE
An almost two hour boat trip on Lake Luzern in heavy mist and light rain.

(Left) View from the Axenstrasse, a remarkable highway cut from solid rock a century ago along together shore of Lake Luzern, which parallels the waters edge and then rises to perhaps a thousand feet, with occasional windowed tunnel s to give superb views of the Alps on the opposite shore (in light rain).

blocks.text: The walled town of Gruyeres is built on a single hill that is surrounded by mountains. The castle was occupied by the counts of Gruyeres for almost 700 years, until the 16th century. Most of the well preserved houses date from the 15th century. The town gives its name to the world famous cheese produced in the surrounding valley.

blocks.text: Shortly after eight o'clock we arrive at the hamlet of Semsaales, observe the ancient Hotel of Savages, and decide to spend the night. We get a large room on the third floor with two double beds to sleep four for a total of $6.50; comfortable without conveniences, but plenty of atmosphere. Late supper next to a love sick couple oblivious of our presence.
Wednesdayday, July 26 - drive 130 miles; it's simply impossible to make time as we know it at home... with the mountain roads, and so much to see.

blocks.text: South of Montreux—is the famous Castle of Chillon, begun in the 9th century and enlarged through the years. During the Middle Ages it was a stronghold of the Dukes of Savoy. The Castle is remarkably well preserved and restored.
Lord Byron's" Prisoner of Chillon" recounts the suffering of Bonivard, who was chained in a dungeon of the Castle for four years...a grim spot indeed.

The terrain necessitates thousands of bridges. These two, one for a railroad and one for the highway, span a deep gorge.

blocks.text: From Brig we begin the climb over the Simplon Pass, one of the most famous of Alpine passes. The road was first built by Napoleon to consolidate his empire. As we climb we can look back upon the Rhone Valley and the Bernese Alps, while far below our winding road there appear s to be only a sickening void.
The top at last. It is almost dark.

From Brig we begin the climb over the Simplon Pass, one of the most famous of Alpine passes. The road was first built by Napoleon to consolidate his empire. As we climb we can look back upon the Rhone Valley and the Bernese Alps, while far below our winding road there appear s to be only a sickening void.

The top at last. It is almost dark.

blocks.text: Beyond St. Moritz encounter first difficulties in securing accommodations for night. Inquire a score of places...everything filled. Decide to cross Fluela Pass in darkness (Louise driving)...road repairs...no idea what lies over the side...snow along road...only three cars...finally arrive Davos...first inquiry.

Friday, July 28 - Hotel, with breakfast in Davos. This sports center claims to have the longest ski run in the world. Proceed northwest through more gentle mountain terrain...the high Alps are behind us.
Old Swiss towntown of Maienfeld with town square; some buildings with walls in fresco.

blocks.text: The principality of Lichtenstein, bordering on Switzerland and Austria, contains only sixty square miles, is surrounded by moun-tains, is closely allied with Switzerland (no customs at the border), and has as its largest town the capital at Vaduz with only 3,000 people. When we passed through Vaduz the town was gaily decorated with flags and pennants hung across the streets; discover later a member of the royal family is to be married.
Quickly pass through Lichtenstein to enter the extreme western corner of Austria, to the walled city of Feldkirch.

First view of Lichtenstein:
a castle on top of a hill and a large church.

The town of Feldkirch has a large square with open air markets. The old buildings have a pleasing quaintness. Everything is immaculate. Note in the center picture the building with the steer head above the second floor.
Time is running short – we must return to Switzerlandland, and Zurich.

blocks.text: Covered bridge over the Thur River en route to Zurich.
The highly cultivated farm lands in eastern Switzerland. Hay is piled on stakes to dry.

Night in a small town outside Zurich. Modest hotel run by Italians ($3.50 for two in one large room with double beds). Spaghetti for supper, only food we recognize on menu; no English spoken; enough spaghetti for twice our number.

Saturday,
July 29 -
a quick check at American Express for mail...then good by to Louise and Marilyn who drive to Italy...Gordon and Kitty to Paris by train.

blocks.text: Depart Zurich at 2:10 P. M. by train...almost miss transfer to French train in Basel....arrive Paris 10:30 P. M. Trains in Europe are clean, comfortable and on time. Travel most of way with French couple; husband a civil employee who has taught himself to speak English; we manage fairly well.

Daniel Croz, whom Cindy knew during her year in Paris and who visited us in 1965, is waiting for us at the train station. After a reunion at a sidewalk cafe, Daniel drives us to our hotel, where he had made the reservations. Then proceed by car to get a first fleeting impression of the city at night, starting with Montmartre and then the Basilique du Sacre-Coeur to the Grand Boulevards, many famous buildings, to the Left Bank and Les Halles. To bed, finally at 3 A. M.

Harry's New York Bar,
5 rue Daunou, rendez-
vous for Americans in
Paris since before
World War I. Literati,
sportsmen, performers,
the wealthy, the dil-
ettante, the average
tourist, all have found their way to
Harry's Bar.
Many of the interesting restaurants, and the least expensive, are located in the small side streets. Grand Restaurant Colbert is found after an hour's search on foot.

blocks.text: Paris is everything we had heard about...and more. Gay, urbane, ornately beautiful, with some of the world's greatest museums, home to artists of every persuasion, Paris offers more of a variety of sightseeing and of entertainment than probably any other city.
The River Seine divides Paris roughly into two equal sections. In the far distance is Montmartre, with the Church of Sacre-Coeur, highest point in the city.

( Opposite page) The Eiffel Tower, erected in 1887 for the Paris Exposition, rises to 984 feet above the city. We content ourselves with one of the lower levels when a long line of sight-seers convinces us it would take more than an hour to get to the top.

blocks.text: Two exceptional dinners with Daniel: one, an Algerian restaurant, where we have had “couscous” for the first time, followed by a heavy coffee and tea poured into a small cup from a distance of two feet with never a drop spilled; and a steak dinner supervised by the proprietor himself impeccably dressed and sporting a handle bar mustache of magnificent proportions.
The Arch of Triumph, at the head of the Champs Elysees, was begun in 1806 and completed 30 years later. It commemorates the victories of Napoleon.
The Cathedral of Notre-Dame, most famous of all Gothic cathedrals, had its beginning in the 12th century. Coronations and state funerals cover the years.
The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel at the Tuileries gardens and the Louvre, another monument to Napoleon's conquests. .

blocks.text: The Palais du Louvre is the largest art building in the world, containing room after room after room of art treasures in every form from earliest times, through Egyptian Greek and Roman periods to the present.
Venus de Milo
Winged Victory of Samothrace.
These two masterpieces, known to every one, occupy special places of honor.

blocks.text: Tuesday, August 1 - fly from Orly Airport outside Paris to London in one hour, arriving at 6:45 P. M.

By bus and taxi reach our hotel, the West End, on Gloucester Place where reservations have been made. Our room a large one on the first floor with twin beds at $14 a night, including a sumptuous breakfast.
In light rain stand in line a half block long to see Madame Tussaud's wax museum, gallery of the famous and infamous, past and present (about 85¢).

blocks.text: The Tower of London, built by William the Conqueror in the 11th century, has been the residence of royalty, a mint, a prison; and it has been the scene of so many murders, political executions and treacherous intrigue that one can only wonder how the nation survived.
The very walls have an air of foreboding. It is a grim and melancholy place. What a miserable place to live, or (much worse) be imprisoned!

blocks.text: Tower Bridge across the Thames was built in 1894; has a hydraulic lift to allow ships to pass.
Piccadilly Circus, London's entertainment hub with theaters, restaurants and night clubs; gathering place for beatniks; statue of Eros in center. Signs look familiar.
Historic Trafalgar Square, memorial to Admiral Nelson who stands atop a 184-foot high column. The Church of St. Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

blocks.text: Friday, August 4 — fly from London to Edinburgh; 4:45 to 6:05 P. M.; met at airport by Mrs. Stewart.
First sight of Scotland as our plane emerges from heavy clouds approaching Edinburgh airport. Land in light rain.
Angus and Eugene Stewart, parents of Vickie with whom Cindy occupies house in Georgetown, USA, who entertain us in their home for three nights and who show us the Highlands.
Two world famous bridges across the Firth of Forth near Edinburgh. The suspension bridge, second longest in Europe, carries the highway; while the older cantilever bridge is for a railroad.

blocks.text: (Below) The castle at Stirling looks much like the one at Edinburgh. Seven battle-fields are nearby, including famous Bannockburn (1314) where Robert Bruce routed the numerically superior English army of Edward II to secure independence for Scotland and to become her undistinguished king.

Sir Walter Scott's poem, "The Lady of the Lake" (1810), is said to center about Lock Katrine.

blocks.text: These shaggy, long horned beasts are Highland cattle, a breed never seen before.

The Scottish Highlands, their rugged beauty and character of a haunting wilderness, have been described in song and story. They are strange mountains generally covered with a green carpet of heather to the very tops, but lacking trees. Sheep range far and wide; people and habitats are far spaced.

blocks.text: Monday, August 7 – an early flight (7:55 A. M.) from Edinburgh to London. A two-hour wait at London airport for the BOAC Boeing 707 which takes us to New York, arriving at Kennedy International Airport at 1:40 P. M. (changes in time again).
Cindy and Kathy meet us at Kennedy Airport...drop Kathy in Larchmont...Cindy accompanies us to Lancaster...our trip is ended.

Approximate cost of trip to Europe ------- $1,300.
Cost of pictures and the preparation of this album-- 160.

Great Britain - Ireland Jamaica - New Zealand
Exchange rates based on official rate of:
1.0 pound equals US $2.80 (pennies) £(shillings)
5 pounds, 4 shillings and sixpence is written 5/4/6

Travel in Europe involves not only a language differential, but a monetary one as well. Each new country has a currency of its own. We do not stay in any one country long enough to become very familiar with the exchange ratio, but with the aid of a currency converter we manage well enough.
